title: Synthetic Recap
body:
ORLANDO – In a season defined by Michael Jordan’s final march with the Chicago Bulls, it was a young star’s historic eruption that stole the show.

On a night when the legendary Bulls arrived in Orlando, all narratives were shattered by Tracy McGrady’s stunning 62-point performance, powering the Magic to a 106-98 victory. While the final score indicates a team triumph, this was, unequivocally, the McGrady game.

From the opening tip, McGrady was uncontainable. He attacked the rim with a ferocious blend of athleticism and grace, his silky-smooth jumper falling from all angles. The Bulls, a team renowned for its defensive discipline, threw multiple defenders at the 19-year-old phenom, but to no avail. He was simply in a different stratosphere, scoring at will in a performance that left the Orlando Arena in a state of delirious disbelief with each successive basket.

The Bulls, as they so often did, fought back with trademark resilience. Scottie Pippen provided 23 points of steady leadership, but even his all-around brilliance was rendered a subplot. Michael Jordan, though limited, still managed to chip in 19 points. Yet, on this night, they were helpless spectators to a one-man offensive clinic.

McGrady’s 62 points weren't just a career-high; they were a declaration. It was a scoring barrage that announced the arrival of a new, devastating force in the league, capable of single-handedly dismantling the NBA's most vaunted dynasty. The Magic needed every one of them to secure the win, as the final box score showed no other Orlando player even cracked the 20-point mark.

History will remember the 1997-98 season as Jordan’s last dance. But on this particular evening in Orlando, the music was all McGrady’s—a breathtaking solo that echoed through the rafters and signaled the dawn of a new era.
